laws.summary: Employers are prohibited from asking applicants about wage or salary history or relying on such information when determining compensation.
requirements: Cannot ask applicants about wage or salary history
Cannot rely on wage history when determining compensation
Applies to written, oral, or third-party inquiries
Applicants may voluntarily disclose salary history
Employers may verify only voluntarily disclosed salary history
Applies to all employers statewide
laws.notes: Violations may result in civil penalties and enforcement by CT Department of Labor.

laws.summary: Employers must disclose wage ranges to applicants and employees and must ensure equal pay for comparable work unless justified by lawful factors.
laws.statute_citation: Conn. Gen. Stat. § 31-40z; Connecticut Equal Pay Act
requirements: Must provide wage range to applicant upon request
Must provide wage range before offer if not previously requested
Must provide wage range upon hire
Must provide wage range upon promotion or transfer
Employees cannot be prohibited from discussing wages
Pay differences must be based on bona fide factors (seniority, merit, education, experience, etc.)
Cannot retaliate against employees for wage disclosure
laws.notes: Unlike CA/NY, salary ranges are not required in job postings, but must be disclosed pre-offer or upon request.

laws.summary: Non-competes are governed by common law reasonableness. Non-competes for physicians are statutorily prohibited.
requirements: Physician non-competes are void and unenforceable
Non-competes must be reasonable in scope, geography, and duration for other workers
Must protect legitimate business interest
Courts evaluate employer hardship vs employee burden
Overly broad clauses are commonly invalidated
laws.effective_date: Physician ban since 2016; common law ongoing
laws.notes: No broad ban like California; enforcement depends heavily on courts.

laws.summary: Employers must follow anti-discrimination rules when using criminal history and must comply with federal FCRA procedures when using consumer reports.
laws.statute_citation: Conn. Gen. Stat. § 46a-80; Fair Credit Reporting Act (15 U.S.C. § 1681)
requirements: Cannot deny employment solely due to criminal record
Must consider nature of offense, time elapsed, and job relevance
Must consider rehabilitation evidence
State agencies cannot ask criminal history on initial application
If using background check vendor: must obtain written consent
Must provide pre-adverse action notice if report may be used negatively
Must provide copy of report and rights before final adverse action
Must follow FCRA adverse action procedures
laws.notes: Private employers must be cautious even without statewide ban-the-box.

laws.summary: Connecticut mandates paid sick leave and also protects certain statutory leaves such as jury duty, voting leave, and lactation accommodations.
laws.statute_citation: Conn. Gen. Stat. § 31-57r et seq.; § 51-247a (jury duty); § 31-51ll (lactation)
requirements: Paid sick leave accrues at 1 hour per 30 hours worked
Employees can use up to 40 hours per year
Applies to increasing number of employers from 2024–2027
Employees must be allowed leave for jury duty
Employers cannot penalize employees for jury duty attendance
Employers must provide reasonable lactation accommodations
Employers must allow unpaid time off to vote if required
laws.notes: Offer letters should not contradict statutory leave entitlements.

laws.summary: Connecticut prohibits discrimination against registered medical marijuana users and provides employment protections for off-duty cannabis use, with exceptions.
laws.statute_citation: Conn. Gen. Stat. § 21a-408p; Responsible and Equitable Regulation of Adult-Use Cannabis Act
requirements: Cannot discriminate solely due to medical marijuana use
Cannot refuse employment solely due to off-duty cannabis use
Safety-sensitive positions may be exempt
Employers may prohibit impairment during work hours
Drug testing policies must be in writing
Policies must be applied consistently
laws.notes: Blanket zero-tolerance policies can easily violate CT law.

laws.summary: Arbitration agreements are generally enforceable but must be procedurally fair and not unconscionable.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act; Connecticut contract law
requirements: Agreement must be voluntary and clear
Must not be one-sided
Must provide reasonable notice
Must allow neutral arbitrator
Unconscionable clauses may be struck by courts

laws.summary: Employment is presumed at-will but subject to numerous statutory and common law exceptions.
laws.statute_citation: Common law; Connecticut Fair Employment Practices Act (CFEPA)
requirements: Employment is at-will unless contract states otherwise
Cannot terminate for discriminatory reasons
Cannot retaliate for protected activity
Public policy violations create wrongful termination claims
Employee handbooks can create implied contracts
laws.notes: Offer letters must avoid language that undermines at-will status unintentionally.

laws.summary: Connecticut law prohibits discrimination and harassment based on a wide range of protected characteristics beyond federal law.
requirements: Cannot discriminate based on race, color, religion, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation
Cannot discriminate based on age (40+), disability, national origin, ancestry
Cannot discriminate based on pregnancy, marital status, veteran status
Harassment-free workplace required
Retaliation against complainants is prohibited
laws.notes: Offer letters and employment terms must not imply exclusion or preference.

data_quality.sources: Connecticut General Statutes, Connecticut Department of Labor, CHRO guidance, official state agency publications

additional_notes.general_guidance: Connecticut is highly employee-protective. Employers must be cautious with compensation language, cannabis policies, and benefit disclosures.
enforcement_agencies: Connecticut Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities (CHRO)
